articles.headline: The Jobless Rate May Have Hit Its Peak
articles.snippet: The monthly survey by the Institute for Supply Management suggests that the 10.2 percent unemployment rate in October was the peak.
articles.abstract: The monthly survey by the Institute for Supply Management suggests that the 10.2 percent unemployment rate in October was the peak.
articles.lead_paragraph: The peak in unemployment in the United States has probably passed, according to one economic indicator that has proved reliable in all 10 previous recessions since World War II.

articles.headline: Foreclosures Can Offer Deals, but Buyer Beware
articles.snippet: Houses in foreclosure often sell for 15 to 20 percent less than comparable in the same neighborhood.
articles.abstract: Houses in foreclosure often sell for 15 to 20 percent less than comparable in the same neighborhood.
articles.lead_paragraph: So you’re looking to buy a new home, and you think a foreclosed house may be the best deal. You’ve probably noticed, then, that many of the big banks’ Web sites are beginning to look a bit like real estate brokerages, showcasing the many properties that they’ve repossessed.

articles.headline: From Pocket to Stage, Music in the Key of iPhone
articles.snippet: The Stanford Mobile Phone Orchestra pushes the frontiers of computer music using iPhones as instruments.
articles.abstract: The Stanford Mobile Phone Orchestra pushes the frontiers of computer music using iPhones as instruments.
articles.lead_paragraph: PALO ALTO, Calif.  An expectant hush fell over the audience as the director of the chamber ensemble, Ge Wang, came out and asked them to turn off their cellphones. The seven other musicians, dressed in black, filed in and took their positions in a circle.
articles.byline: By Claire Cain Miller and Miguel Helft

articles.headline: Indian Soothsayers Offer Tips Using Numbers and Names
articles.snippet: Numerologists in India offer advice that uses mathematical formulas, and market themselves through infomercials, or writing newspaper columns or with Web sites.
articles.abstract: Numerologists in India offer advice that uses mathematical formulas, and market themselves through infomercials, or writing newspaper columns or with Web sites.
articles.lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India  Sanjay B. Jumaani has your number  and for a fee he can offer you an upgrade.

articles.headline: G.I.’s Learning to Stand Down as Iraqis Step In
articles.snippet: American soldiers’ role in urban areas has changed, meaning they now must let local forces handle security, even if imperfectly.
articles.abstract: American soldiers’ role in urban areas has changed, meaning they now must let local forces handle security, even if imperfectly.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIRKUK, Iraq  The soldiers of Battery B were on a routine walk through a downtown market when they heard the noise: a low crack that was followed by a plume of black smoke 500 yards away. The soldiers’ attention sharpened, their assault weapons swung at the ready. A few months ago, they would have been on the move by now.

articles.headline: Questioning a $30,000-a-Month Cancer Drug
articles.snippet: Experts question the value of the expensive lymphoma drug Folotyn, which shrinks tumors but has not been shown to prolong lives.
articles.abstract: Experts question the value of the expensive lymphoma drug Folotyn, which shrinks tumors but has not been shown to prolong lives.
articles.lead_paragraph: A newly approved chemotherapy drug will cost about $30,000 a month, a sign that the prices of cancer medicines are continuing to rise despite growing concern about health care costs.

articles.headline: How Obama Came to Plan for ‘Surge’ in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: When the history of the Obama presidency is written, the day he decided on a troop surge may prove to be a turning point, a high-stakes gamble to turn around a losing war.
articles.abstract: When the history of the Obama presidency is written, the day he decided on a troop surge may prove to be a turning point, a high-stakes gamble to turn around a losing war.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  On the afternoon he held the eighth meeting of his Afghanistan review, President Obama arrived in the White House Situation Room ruminating about war. He had come from Arlington National Cemetery, where he had wandered among the chalky white tombstones of those who had fallen in the rugged mountains of Central Asia.

articles.headline: 4 Ex-Governors Craving Jobs of Yore
articles.snippet: Four former governors who have grown old enough since leaving office to qualify for senior citizen discounts want their old jobs back.
articles.abstract: Four former governors who have grown old enough since leaving office to qualify for senior citizen discounts want their old jobs back.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore.  Over the course of the summer, four men of a certain age looked around their respective states and registered displeasure. They concluded that they could do things better  yet again.

articles.headline: In Animated Videos, News and Guesswork Mix
articles.snippet: A video that simulates Tiger Woods’s accident has drawn attention to a new world of pseudo-journalism in Taiwan.
articles.abstract: A video that simulates Tiger Woods’s accident has drawn attention to a new world of pseudo-journalism in Taiwan.
articles.lead_paragraph: Welcome to the new world of Maybe Journalism  a best guess at the news as it might well have been, rendered as a video game and built on a bed of pure surmise.

articles.headline: Apple’s Game Changer, Downloading Now
articles.snippet: As the Apple App Store evolves, it is changing the goals of developers, bolstering sales of iPhones and causing competitors to overhaul their product lines.
articles.abstract: As the Apple App Store evolves, it is changing the goals of developers, bolstering sales of iPhones and causing competitors to overhaul their product lines.
articles.lead_paragraph: IAN LYNCH SMITH, a shaggy-haired ball of energy in his late 30s, beams as he ticks off some of the games that Freeverse, his little Brooklyn software company, has landed on the iPhone App Store’s coveted (and ever-changing) list of best-selling downloads: Moto Chaser, Flick Fishing, Flick Bowling and Skee-ball.

articles.headline: Is Money Tainting the Plasma Supply?
articles.snippet: Hundreds, probably thousands, of Mexicans come to the United States to trade their plasma for dollars.
articles.abstract: Hundreds, probably thousands, of Mexicans come to the United States to trade their plasma for dollars.
articles.lead_paragraph: Eagle Pass, Tex.

articles.headline: Why Treasury Needs a Plan B for Mortgages
articles.snippet: The Treasury’s mortgage-modification program relies on interest-rate reductions rather than principal cuts, which could cause a problem.
articles.abstract: The Treasury’s mortgage-modification program relies on interest-rate reductions rather than principal cuts, which could cause a problem.
articles.lead_paragraph: AFTER months of playing pretend, the Treasury Department conceded last week that the Home Affordable Modification Program, its plan to aid troubled homeowners by changing the terms of their mortgages, was a dud. The 10-month-old program is going nowhere, the Treasury said, because big institutions charged with implementing it are dragging their feet.

articles.headline: Aid Gives Alternative to African Orphanages
articles.snippet: Experts are endorsing a program in Malawi that gives money to poor extended families who take in orphans.
articles.abstract: Experts are endorsing a program in Malawi that gives money to poor extended families who take in orphans.
articles.lead_paragraph: MCHINJI DISTRICT, Malawi  The Home of Hope orphanage provides Chikodano Lupanga, 15, with three nutritious meals a day, new school uniforms, sensible black shoes and a decent education.

articles.headline: Charities Rise, Costing U.S. Billions in Tax Breaks
articles.snippet: The number of public charities has soared, resulting in more than $50 billion a year in lost tax revenue.
articles.abstract: The number of public charities has soared, resulting in more than $50 billion a year in lost tax revenue.
articles.lead_paragraph: The number of organizations that can offer their donors a tax break in the name of charity has grown more than 60 percent in the United States, to 1.1 million, in just a decade.

articles.headline: Local Governments Offer Data to Software Tinkerers
articles.snippet: Many local governments are turning over big chunks of data to programmers to create useful Web sites and apps.
articles.abstract: Many local governments are turning over big chunks of data to programmers to create useful Web sites and apps.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  A big pile of city crime reports is not all that useful. But what if you could combine that data with information on bars, sidewalks and subway stations to find the safest route home after a night out?

articles.headline: Two Reality Shows Stir Publicity and Anger
articles.snippet: A show about Italian-Americans has brought accusations of stereotyping, and another about reuniting adoptees with their birth parents has riled adoption groups.
articles.abstract: A show about Italian-Americans has brought accusations of stereotyping, and another about reuniting adoptees with their birth parents has riled adoption groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: If a reality television show is not generating outrage these days, it seems not to be doing its job.

articles.headline: No Firm Plans for a U.S. Exit in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: Top administration officials said Sunday that any troop pullout beginning in July 2011 would be slow.
articles.abstract: Top administration officials said Sunday that any troop pullout beginning in July 2011 would be slow.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration sent a forceful public message Sunday that American military forces could remain in Afghanistan for a long time, seeking to blunt criticism that President Obama had sent the wrong signal in his war-strategy speech last week by projecting July 2011 as the start of a withdrawal.

articles.headline: Reality TV’s Glare Hits High Office
articles.snippet: After the covert atmosphere of the Bush years, the openness of the Obama White House was refreshing. It’s time to close the curtain a bit.
articles.abstract: After the covert atmosphere of the Bush years, the openness of the Obama White House was refreshing. It’s time to close the curtain a bit.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Barack Obama became president, he promised a “new era of openness.” After almost a year of a media diet that seemed to be all-Obama, all-the-time that concluded in a reality-program couple crashing a state dinner at the White House, I’d be O.K. with the kimono closing a bit.

articles.headline: Secret’s Out: Sample Sales Move Online
articles.snippet: More sample sales are moving online as new private-sale sites have become a thriving corner of online commerce.
articles.abstract: More sample sales are moving online as new private-sale sites have become a thriving corner of online commerce.
articles.lead_paragraph: Daniela Busciglio still winces at the memory of shivering in line for hours to get into New York sample sales, then shoving her way through throngs of other shoppers looking for deals on designer clothes.
articles.byline: By Claire Cain Miller and Jenna Wortham

articles.headline: Rules for Congress Curb but Don’t End Junkets
articles.snippet: Some lawmakers evade ethics rules meant to limit junkets hosted by private groups and companies.
articles.abstract: Some lawmakers evade ethics rules meant to limit junkets hosted by private groups and companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Representative F. James Sensenbrenner Jr., a Wisconsin Republican, toured a prince’s vineyard and castle in Liechtenstein and spent an afternoon at a ski resort in the Alps  all at the expense of a group of European companies.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Eric Lichtblau

articles.headline: Promoting the Car Phone, Despite Risks
articles.snippet: Industry pioneers have long been aware of the risks of multitasking behind the wheel, but still marketed cellphones to drivers.
articles.abstract: Industry pioneers have long been aware of the risks of multitasking behind the wheel, but still marketed cellphones to drivers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Martin Cooper, who developed the first portable cellphone, recalled testifying before a Michigan state commission about the risks of talking on a phone while driving.

articles.headline: U.S. Forecasts Smaller Loss From Bailout of Banks
articles.snippet: New estimates, of a loss of $42 billion out of $370 billion lent, could lower the administration’s deficit forecast.
articles.abstract: New estimates, of a loss of $42 billion out of $370 billion lent, could lower the administration’s deficit forecast.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Treasury Department expects to recover all but $42 billion of the $370 billion it has lent to ailing companies since the financial crisis began last year, with the portion lent to banks actually showing a slight profit, according to a new Treasury report.

articles.headline: Big Paydays for Rescuers in the Crisis
articles.snippet: In less than two years, many big sovereign wealth funds have reaped huge gains from bailing out financial institutions.
articles.abstract: In less than two years, many big sovereign wealth funds have reaped huge gains from bailing out financial institutions.
articles.lead_paragraph: The white knights that came to the rescue of banks during the financial crisis are going home, with their pockets full of bounty from their good deeds.

articles.headline: NBC-Comcast Deal Puts Broadcast TV in Doubt
articles.snippet: Despite Comcast’s assurances, employees at NBC have expressed anxiety about the cable giant’s bid for control of NBC Universal.
articles.abstract: Despite Comcast’s assurances, employees at NBC have expressed anxiety about the cable giant’s bid for control of NBC Universal.
articles.lead_paragraph: From Studio 6B at 30 Rockefeller Center, NBC brought Milton Berle, Jack Paar and Johnny Carson into the nation’s living rooms, then broadcast local news to New York City for decades. Last Thursday, it was a stage for a cable takeover as Comcast announced a plan to acquire NBC Universal.
